MONDAY, OCTOBER 24, 1904.

div.head: EGYPT AND THE AGREEMENT
div.p: In reference to the letter on the above subject which appeared in our issue of Friday last, we do not think that our diplomats will be guilty of any discourtesy to France, nor will the "entente cordiale" between the two countries be in any way endangered, if the Anglo-French Agreement is put in force without waiting for the ratification of the French Chambers, because, if our reading of French law be correct, it is quite possible that this agreement may never be submitted to them, their sanction not being necessary for its validity. According to the present Constitution of France, the power of negotiating and ratifying treaties is, as a general principle, vested in the hands of the President of the Republic; but, as an exception to this principle, treaties of peace and commerce, and those which affect the finances of the State or its territorial area, can only become operative after being voted by the two Chambers in the ordinary form of a law.

Does the Anglo-French Agreement enter into the class of treaties covered by this exception or not? To reply to this question one would require to have a much greater knowledge of the details of the compact and of French Constitutional Law than we lay any claim to. Anyhow it is only fair to suppose that our diplomats have not acted without knowing the views and intentions of the French Government, which will probably do its utmost to prevent a measure which is so far-reaching in its effect and which covers so much terrain brulant from being the subject of a heated party debate in the French Chambers. For, as was inevitable, while the principle of the agreement as a whole is accepted on both sides of the Channel with enthusiasm, there is nevertheless in both countries much opposition to its details founded on local considerations and interests.

Some authorities hold that, since every treaty is liable ultimately to affect the finances of the State, the above exception practically reduces the President's power of treaty-making to a mere form and subjects the validity of all treaties to the ratification of the Chambers. This, however, is not the view the view of the French Government nor of the French Chambers themselves. It seems to be an established principle that treaties of alliance are not included amongst those requiring the sanction of the Chambers. For instance, the treaty between Russia and France which is the basis of the alliance between the two countries has never been communicated to or ratified by the French Chambers, but nobody thinks of questioning its validity on that account. The same is the case with the Treaty of Berlin 1878, to which France was one of the signatories.

div.head:
THE WAR.
BOTH ARMIES INACTIVE.
INDICATIONS OF RENEWAL OF BATTLE.

div.p: General Kuropatkin reports that the Japanese have precipitately abandoned Sha-ho-pu, General Kuropatkin reports that the Japa a village situated on the south bank of the Sha-Ho, leaving a quantity of arms and ammunition. (Reuter.)

Reuter's correspondent at the Russian headquarters reports that both armies are comparatively inactive. They are replenishing their ammunition, there are indications of an early renewal of the battle, and that the Russians intend again to take the offensive. (Reuter.)

General Sakharoff reports that no serious fighting occurred yesterday. The offensive movement against the Japanese right is, apparently, not yet sufficiently developed to lead to an encounter on a large scale. The cold is very severe. The Russians are suffering greatly owing to their tents being inadequate. (Reuter.)
(Official). The Russians are massing on the Japanese right. 200 cavalry have crossed the Tait-se Ho, east of Pen-si-hu, and are advancing westward.
(Reuter.)

div.head: THE CASUALTIES.
div.p: Reuter's correspondent with General Oku reports that the casualties of the left army until the 14th inst. amount to only 5,100, of which the greater part are slightly wounded. The casualties of the Russians who opposed General Oku are estimated at the equivalent of an army corps. The Russian killed and wounded are put down by Marshal Oyama at 60,000. (Reuter.)

div.head: MORE RUSSIAN RESERVES CALLED OUT.
div.p: An Ukase calls out for immediate active service the reserves in 120 military districts, which have hitherto been untouched. (R.)

div.head: THE CASE OF THE "ALLANTON."
div.p: The Supreme Prize Court here has annulled the judgment of the Vladivostok Court regarding the S.S. Allanton, mentioned on the 27th June, and ordered the immediate release of the vessel and cargo.
(Reuter.)

div.head: BALTIC FLEET STOPS STEAMER.
div.p: The Baltic fleet stopped a steamer off the Isle of Wight this afternoon. (Reuter.)

div.head: RUSSIA AND GERMANY.
div.p: The Russian Military attaché has been attached to the suite of the Emperor William, and the German Military attaché to that of the Tsar, as in the days of Alexander II. and William I. This renewal of the old arrangement is regarded as indicating a close personal and political bond between the two Governments, and the complete confidence of Russian military authorities in the friendliness of Germany.
(Reuter.)

div.head:
A SERIOUS INCIDENT.
BALTIC FLEET FIRES ON BRITISH FISHING FLEET.
TWO STEAMERS SUNK.

div.p: The Russian Baltic fleet has passed through the Danish Straits. (Havas.)
The Russian Squadron met a fishing flotilla from Hull in the North Sea. For reasons which are as yet unexplained it opened fire. The steamer Crane sank. Several men were wounded. (Havas.)
The Baltic fleet passed here this afternoon going westwards. It is rumoured that they ran down and sank two Hull fishing smacks in the North Sea, drowning 18 fishermen. (Reuter.)

The solicitors for the owners of 50 Hull trawlers have notified the Foreign Office and Admiralty that an attack was made upon the boats by the Baltic Fleet. They state that the first portion of the Baltic fleet passed the fishing ground at midnight on Friday. The remainder, however, turned their search-lights on the British trawlers for some time, and then opened fire, the trawler Crane being sunk. The decapitated bodies of the skipper and mate were brought to Hull. The boatswain and others who were wounded are now on board the mission ship. The trawlers Moulmein and Mino have arrived at Hull seriously damaged. The latter has 16 shot holes. It is feared that another trawler has been sunk with all on board. (Reuter.)
The fleet of trawlers has arrived here. They report that the Baltic fleet on Friday night attacked them in the North Sea, and sank two. Two men were killed and many wounded. (R.)

div.head: FRANCE AND THE VATICAN. DEBATE IN THE FRENCH CHAMBER.

div.p: CHAMBER OF DEPUTIES.-M. Combes recalled the attacks of the clergy against the Republic. He said that the Vatican repelled the preponderance of the civil power. M. Combes wanted the liberty of the church, which was a measure compatible with other liberties.
M. Ribot opposed the separation of Church from State. He left the responsibility for it to the Government.
M. Combes put the question of confidence. The Chamber passed a vote of confidence by 325 votes against 257.

CHAMBER OF DEPUTIES. During the debate on the religious policy of the Government, M. Combes declared that, in view of the Vatican's open disregard for the Concordat, the separation of Church and State had become inevitable. The Chamber passed a vote of confidence in the Government by 325 to 237 votes. (R.)
A PARADE of the British Garrison of Cairo will be held at Kasr-el-Nil on the 27th inst. at 7.15 a.m.
STRAY AND OWNERLESS DOGS found in the Boulac district of Cairo during to-night and at the Mousky during to-morrow night will be poisoned by the police.

div.head: CHRYSANTHEMUM SHOW.
div.p: The Alexandria Horticultural Society's annual Chrysanthemum Show will be held at the San Stefano Casino on Saturday and Sunday next.

div.head: PORT SAID-ISMAILIA LINE.
div.p: The preparations which have been made for the official inauguration by the Khedive of the Port Said-Ismailia railway line have been countermanded as the ceremony is not to take place.

div.head: HASHISH SEIZURE.
div.p: The Customs Guards seized 220 kilos of hashish on board the Austrian Lloyd S.S. Amphitrate on Saturday. The drug was concealed in two parcels of luggage and 3 oil tins. The owner has not been found.

div.head: VICTORIA COLLEGE.-
div.p: The number of boys at Victoria College has now reached over one hundred, fifty of whom are new entries this term. The road facing the sea is to be completed shortly, and this will be very convenient for pupils and their friends visiting the College.

div.head: SUEZ CANAL.
div.p: On the 20th inst. 15 vessels passed through the Suez Canal. Of these, 10 were British, 1 Dutch, 1 German, 1 Austrian, 1 Russian, and 1 Spanish. The transit and passenger dues for the day amounted to 444,540.58 frs. The total transit and passenger dues collected from the first to that date on 255 vessels amounted to 6,603,396.24 frs.

div.head: FIRE AT ALEXANDRIA.-
div.p: A fire broke out last evening in a chair factory in Saleh el-Din-street belonging to Messrs. Abraham. and Mattatia. The Alexandria Fire Brigade arrived at about 8 p.m. and the fire was not entirely extinguished until 11.30 p.m. The factory was gutted, the Brigade finally confining itself to saving the surrounding buildings. The origin of the fire has not yet been ascertained. The losses are stated to be covered by insurance.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE
div.p: The Khedive is to-day at Mariout.
Djellal el-Din Pasha was received in audience by his Highness at Montazah on Saturday afternoon.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL AGRICULTURAL SOCIETY.
div.p: The Egyptian Government intend giving the Khedivial Agricultural Society a larger subvention and will organise it on a broader basis to enable it to extend its operations. The nature of the measures to be undertaken is still under discussion.

div.head: GREEK ENTERPRISE IN THE RED SEA
div.p: A new local steam navigation company has been founded under Hellenic auspices for trading between Suez and the Red Sea ports. The steamers will visit regularly the ports of Jeddah, Sheikh el-Bargout, Hodeidah, and Aden from Suez, and will make the return voyage in the same order. The title of the new company will be "The Hellenic Commercial Steam Navigation Company of the Red Sea." The founders of this company are Greek merchants of Alexandria and the Sudan, Messrs. Angelo Capato, Griva Brothers, Stamatopoulo Brothers, and Caralambo Papalexis. These names are alone a sufficient guarantee of the success of the company, as the founders will be the principal clients of the company. Negotiations are nearly completed for the purchase of four large steamers, and the service will begin as soon as the railway from the Nile Valley to the Red Sea is finished.

div.head: SALT AND SODA CO
div.p: Mr. A. H. Hooker writes :- "In the Personal and Social column of Friday's issue of the Egyptian Gazette you mention me as still connected with the Salt and Soda Company. As my connection with the company has ceased, I should be obliged if you would kindly publish the enclosed letters referring to my resignation and oblige."
The following is the text of the letters referred to :-

Gentlemen,– In view of the changes about to take place in the control of the company's affairs--which changes the present Board in the interests of the independent shareholders have opposed by all means in their power--I have no other course open to me than to place my resignation of the position of General Manager of the company's affairs in their hands. This I now do. I wish to put on record my entire agreement with the policy pursued by the Board.

I take this opportunity of expressing my sincere appreciation of the confidence and support extended to me by my Directors during a long period of anxiety and strain, and to assure the Board that had they remained to direct the destinies of the company I should have continued to the best of my power to deserve the consideration they have always shewn me.

Kindly confirm your acceptance of this resignation. It is of course understood that the Company and I are, from the date of such acceptance, relieved from all further obligations whatsoever under my contract for service as General Manager.
I am, Gentlemen, Yours very sincerely, (Signed)
AYERST HENHAM HOOKER, General Manager.
September 23, 1904.

Dear Sir,- I am instructed by my Directors to inform you that, at a Board Meeting held yesterday, your letter of the 23rd inst. tendering your resignation as General Manager of this company was considered, and that they resolved that, taking into consideration all the circumstances connected with the case, they had no option but to accept same, subject to the conditions expressed in your said letter, namely that both you and the company are henceforth relieved from all obligations whatsoever under the terms of your contract for service as General Manager of the Company.

The Chairman and the Board generally desire me to express to you their high sense of the great services which you have rendered to the company in Egypt, more especially in the organisation and direction of the Salt Department, and they further wish to emphasize their sense of the high personal character for honour and honesty which has always distinguished your career, both as public servant and as an employé of this company.
Yours faithfully, (Signed)
HENRY J. HUMM, Secretary.
London, 28th September 1904.

div.head: ANGLO-EGYPTIAN BANK
div.p: The London Stock Exchange Committee has appointed a special settling day as under : Anglo-Egyptian Bank, further issue of 20,000 shares of £15 each, £5 paid, Nos. 80,001 to 100,000. The Committee has also ordered the undermentioned security to be quoted in the Official List: Anglo-Egyptian Bank, further issue of 20,000 shares of £15 each, £5 paid, Nos. 80,001 to 100,000.

div.head: DEPARTURE OF H. L. I.
div.p: The Highland Light Infantry left Cairo yesterday for Suez by a special train leaving at 5.30 p.m. Many friends, both civil and military, of the officers and men of the departing regiment were present at the station to bid them farewell.

div.head:
STATE RAILWAYS.
EXTENSION SCHEMES.
A TWO MILLIONS LOAN
div.p: After the sittings of the Railway Commission have been completed, it is probable, in accordance with Lord Cromer's last Report, that the Railway Administration will be allowed to contract a loan of two millions sterling.

In this event, the following scheme of railway extension will be considered, viz., from the Barrage to Ashmoun, giving an alternative line to Tantah, and the linking of Zagazig and Zifta. It may be remembered that the construction of a bridge across the Nile from Zifta to Mit Ghamr has already been decided upon. Finally, there remains the question of further linking the Port Said-Suez line with the State railways of the Delta. But it is not certain whether this will be effected by the construction of a line from Salhieh to Kantara or by the doubling of the Zagazig-Ismailia section.
All these schemes are, of course, provisional, and it cannot be said with any certainty which will be first carried out.

Two of the principal questions the Commission which is expected in Cairo next week) will enquire into, are the reduction of expenses and personnel as well as the replacing of the several military heads of departments by civilians trained in railway traffic management in England.

It is reported that the contemplated change in the administration of the State Railways by the present triumvirate will not take effect as early as was intended, as it is considered advisable to await the decisions arrived at by the Commission of Enquiry and its report before dispensing with two members of the Board and leaving one responsible chief to administer them, as is done in every State Railway throughout Europe.

In consequence of many complaints received lately from the public regarding overcharges and the giving of tickets for wrong destinations, the Board has issued a circular in which travellers are requested to assure themselves before leaving the guichets that their tickets are for the proper destination, and that the price marked on them in French and Arabic is the exact sum the passenger has been charged by the booking clerk. Also that no complaints, written or otherwise, will be considered if made after the passenger has left the guichets.

div.head:
THE RAMLEH RAILWAY.
RELAYING THE CABLE.
div.p: During Saturday night the electric cable of the Alexandria and Ramleh Railway Company was found to have been burnt at the same place as where the recent mishaps occurred in the neighbourhood of the Deaconesses' Hospital. The company determined to cope with these continual accidents by relaying the cable, and yesterday 250 metres of cable were taken up and a new cable, of English manufacture, was put down at this spot at an average depth of sixty centimetres and at some places at a depth of one metre below the surface. The town current was used yesterday and traffic was not stopped.

All interruptions to traffic will be entirely obviated in a fortnight's time, when the reserve cable will be finished and ready for working. The company has been at work on this cable for two and a-half months and it will extend from Karmous to Bulkeley.

According to the conditions imposed by the Alexandria Municipality, in order to pass the cable through the city, it had to be laid at a depth of sixty centimetres below the level of the ground. The present cable was laid a little more than a year ago and now it is found that, owing to the work having been negligently done, in many places the cable is not at the regulation depth below the surface. In some places even it is only at eighteen centimetres below the surface of the earth. Thus any malevolent or mischievous person can easily damage the cable and stop the traffic on the Alexandria and Ramleh Railway line.

The Alexandrian public are apt to blame the Municipal authorities for not taking steps at the present juncture to ensure a better service. But it must be remembered that up to the present the Municipality has no power in this matter, the company only being under the direct control of the Ministry of the Interior. The Municipality for some time past has been in correspondence with the Ministry of the Interior with a view to obtaining control over the company directly. Up to now, however, nothing definite has been decided in regard to this subject.

div.head: FRENCH DEPUTIES
div.p: The elections for the deputés de la nation in Cairo will take place early in December. M. Leroux, of the Sucreries, is mentioned as a probable candidate.

div.head: ABBAS HELMY THEATRE
div.p: Andrea Chenier was given at the Abbas Helmy Theatre yesterday afternoon and on Saturday evening. Signorina Peretti was enthusiastically received and surpassed herself. There was a poor house on Saturday evening, but the matinee yesterday was largely attended and the encores were frequent. In the evening Lucia di Lammermoor was given. Signora Falcone, the wife of the leader of the orchestra, delighted the audience with her performance on the harp. There is nothing to add to the criticism we passed on the occasion of the first representation of this opera.
A bumper house is expected on Wednesday, when Aida will be given, with Signorina Popovitch in the title role and Signora Fabbri as Amneris.

div.head: ANOTHER GLOBE-TROTTER
div.p: Walking 25,000 miles.
Through 16 countries in 1000 days.

Paul Philippe Deutsch, a Hungarian journalist, has just arrived at Alexandria on a globe-trotting expedition extending over 1,000 days. Starting on September 1, 1901, he hopes to complete his task on May 21 next year. His last stopping place was Malta, whence he has travelled here first-class by the Deutsch Levante Linie S.S. Maxos, free of any charge. He also came from Southampton to Malta by the same steamer under the same conditions.

Paul Deutsch has a well-built, athletic figure, somewhat on the short side, but sturdy and vigorous. He speaks most of the European tongues fluently, but English puzzles him. Starting from Buda Pesth, he has already travelled through Roumania, Russia, over the Ural mountains to, Central Siberia, Austria, Germany, Holland, Belgium, France, Italy, Spain, Morocco, Portugal, England, and Malta.
WELCOMED EVERYWHERE.

He has been received everywhere with the greatest courtesy and kindness, and has interviewed many notabilities. The King of Roumania, King Leopold of Belgium, the Emperor Francis-Joseph, President Loubet, and King Carlos of Portugal, besides our own King and Queen, have all granted him a special reception, and M. Deutsch proudly treasures souvenir gifts from them all, including special decorations from King Carlos and the French President, and a handsome watch from King Edward and diamond ring from Queen Alexandra.

Consuls and pro-consuls in every capital have honoured him, and newspapers everywhere have appointed him their special correspondent. In the French capital the Matin gave a special banquet in his honour. His scrap-books already contain cuttings from illustrated articles concerning his tour in most of the European languages. He has reserved a special page for the Egyptian Gazette, the only newspaper he has told his story to in Egypt.

Paul Deutsch has no ambition for record-breaking. He is quite satisfied with walking forty-five kilometres per day for eight days at s stretch, and resting and writing for a week whenever possible. He supports himself by newspaper correspondence en route, and so far has found no special difficulty in doing so. Keeping his eyes open as he goes, and covering reams of paper with copious notes, he carries always at the back of his mind his main purpose - to write a book concerning his travels when he gets home. It should be worth reading. The success of the book is practicually assured since the Hungarian Society of Journalism has already subscribed 20,000 florins and the Hungarian Geographical Society 40,000 florins towards the cost of its production.
WOLVES AND DYNAMITE

Naturally, M. Deutsch has met with many stirring adventures and not a few vicissitudes. Russia and Siberia proved especially trying. The climate was villainous, the natives suspicious and inhospitable, and the distances formidable. His pack of indispensable requisites weighed over 30 lbs., borne on his back on every stage of the journey. On such a tour one must naturally emulate the snail, carrying a house on one's back.

On one occasion, he was attacked by a pack of hungry wolves. It was an awkward contretemps. He carried no firearms, and did not possess even a serviceable knife. Luckily, a solitary cake of dynamite was in his pack. He carried them for the purpose of breaking through ice on the pools to get water.

Desperately he flung the explosive right in the midst of the pack. It exploded with a terrific report. He was thrown to the ground himself with the concussion but was not hurt. Three or four of the wolves were blown to atoms, and more injured. The rest of the pack at once commenced eating their fallen comrades. Without stopping to make a list of the casualties he rushed ahead, and found shelter in a village several miles away.

During his journey, M. Deutsch has worn down 469 pairs of soles, slept 794 nights in civilized beds-the rest in his tent-and walked 195,000,000 paces. He weighed 12 stone 4 lb. when he started, but is reduced to 9st. 10½ lb. In Siberia he contracted a form of scurvy through drinking impure water, which destroyed his lovely Austrian moustachios, loosened six of his front teeth, and marked his face badly. Even yet, he has not got rid of his scorbutic sores, and his teeth are gone for ever.

As for the remainder of his perambulations, he intends proceeding from here to Cairo, Port Said, Salonica, Smyrna, Constantinople, Macedonia, Bulgaria, Servia, and back to Hungary, thus completing his 24,840 miles in 1,000 days. He is staying at the Hotel Abbate, where he can be seen by anyone from 3 to 6 p.m.

div.head: TRANSPORTS AT PORT SAID
div.p: Port Said, Sunday .- H.M. transports Assaye (Capt. E. R. Dowell, R.N.R.) and Sicilia (Capt. G. N. C. Weston, R.N.R.) arrived at Port Said early this morning. The Assaye, homeward bound from Bombay for Southampton, had on board 1,479 troops of all ranks, including women and children. She is also taking home 61 naval ratings. Lt.-Col. M. G. Jackson is the officer commanding. The Sicilia, outward bound for Bombay, had on board 774 troops, and will call at Suez to embark the 1st Battalion Highland Light Infantry. The officer commanding is Colonel A. W. Lysaght, 1st Bedford Regiment. The Sicilia entered the Canal at noon to-day.

div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
div.p: We do not hold ourselves rosponsible for the opinions expressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all, to permit - within certain necessary limita- free discussion.

div.head:
REDUCTION OF GARRISON.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.
div.p: Dear Sir,-I cannot but think that your occasional correspondent who approved of a reduction of the British garrison has little experience of India. He says that India is a country liable to severe famine and discontent, while Egypt is never liable to famine. Bengal, with its 70,000,000, has no knowledge of famines, just as the Egypt of to-day, but the Mahratta country, Rajpootana and Sindh are very liable to famines, and it is there that all mutinies and risings began. In the same way the Sudan is a country very liable to famines, and it is there that the troubles of the past have sprung and where those of the future will come. Does your correspondent for one moment imagine that the Arabs of the Sudan are ignorant of what the Arabs of the Aden hinterland and Somaliland have done and are doing ? Egypt and the Sudan, or the country under the joint British and Egyptian Governments on the Nile, is comparable to India. The British army in India is strong enough to hold the balance between the Mohamedans and Hindus of India, and while it is strong enough we shall hold India. The day it is too weak to do so we shall lose India. The Egyptian army in the Sudan with a sufficient backbone of British soldiers is strong enough to master the Sudan martial tribes if they rebel. If, howeyer, the British garrison is not strong enough to hold the balance, the day may come when Turkey will be asked by Europe to protect the European interests which we have failed to safeguard.

We can no more separate the Sudan from Egypt than we can separate Mahrattaland, Rajpootana and Sindh from Bengal. I do not suppose that there are five men in Egypt who know whether Lord Cromer was outvoted at the meeting of the Imperial Defence Committee, or whether he was not. Who knows whether the General was consulted and what advice he gave? The very worst thing for the Empire is an Imperial Defence Committee presided over by a party man like the Prime Minister, who would be tempted to put the exigencies of party finance before the true needs of the Empire. If the King, or the Prince of Wales, or the Duke of Connaught had been president, we Britishers who live abroad would have been better served. It is impossible that a man like Lord Cromer, an Imperialist of Imperialists, who thinks in hundreds of thousands of pounds when he is not thinking in millions, would for one moment have let a paltry saving of a fraction of £84,000 weigh with him in so momentous a question. I agree entirely with the sentiments of the Great Duke as quoted by "Disgusted" and am much afraid that in this country we may have to regret that the Imperial Defence Committee began business by being in such a d--d hurry to reduce the garrisons of the Empire.
Yours truly,

div.head:
THE CAIRO STREETS
TO THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.
div.p: Sir,- On the 15th instant, you were good enough to publish a letter of mine calling attention to the danger to life and limb through the obstruction in the Sharia el Boustan. I thought that my friends of the Tanzim would have taken the hint and compelled the builders to remove it, but nothing to the sort has yet happened. On the contrary, as I was passing through that locality to-day, I noticed that iron rails had been heaped up and that there were more piles of cement and other building materials than on the former occasion. Really, my friends of the Tanzim seem quite incorrigible. Not even the special pleading of "Pedestrian" will justify their negligence in this instance for the building material reaches to within a foot of the middle of the road, and "Pedestrian" did not carry his argument quite so far as that. Oh, my friends of the Tanzim, you are brave or callous indeed! Nothing, not even a leading article in. the Egyptian Gazette, will arouse you from. your lethal slumber ! What boots it, my fortunate friends, whether the public is inconvenienced or placed in jeopardy so long as you draw your salaries regularly? If damages had to be paid it would not come out of your pockets. Your position is, I confess, from certain points of view, truly enviable.
I am, etc.,

div.head: YOU NEVER KNOW YOUR LUCK
div.p: We publish in another column the advertisement of SAMUEL HECKSCHER SENR., OF HAMBURG.
This house has acquired a high reputation for the prompt payment of amounts won by persons here and in all parts of the world.
We would strongly recommend our readers to take particular notice of Mr. Heckscher's announcement and try their luck to win A FORTUNE. [ADVT.]

div.head: GRAND HOTEL BONNARD, ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: 2s. PER DAY. WINE INCLUDED.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Ghazi Muhktar Pasha, Imperial Ottoman High Commissioner, will leave for Cairo on Thursday.
M. de la Boulinière, French Diplomatic Agent and Consul General, is expected to return from leave on the 3rd proxo.
Chevalier de Puscariu, Austro-Hungarian Consul at Alexandria, arrived this morning from Trieste.
Herr von Mohl, the German Commissioner of the Public Debt, has arrived in Germany on leave of absence and is stopping at Arnshaugh Castle, Neustadt-on-the-Orla.
Miralai Hopkinson Bey, Commandant of the Alexandria City Police, who has been on a shooting trip to Asia Minor, returned to Alexandria from Smyrna to-day.
The Hon. Mrs. Hopkinson is arriving from Europe on Monday next by the Austrian Lloyd steamer from Trieste.
Major W. A. Boulnois is leaving Cairo for Wan, in the Bahr el-Ghazal province.
Maitre Carton de Wiart has arrived at Cairo from Europe.
Dr. A. J. M. Bentley arrives by the P. amd O. Moldavia at Port Said to-morrow.
Mrs. Stanton, wife of Col. Stanton, Governor of Khartoum, will also arrive by the P. and O. Moldavia and will go to the Grand Continental Hotel, Cairo.
Mr. Nestor Gianaclis returned yesterday to Cairo from his villa residence at San Stefano, where he has spent the summer.
Mr. and Mrs. Hesket Pembroke, who have for many years patronised Egypt, will arrive at the Grand Continental Hotel, Cairo, on Wednesday. They travel by the P. and O. Moldavia.
We are glad to be able to announce that Dr. Petrou, who has been very seriously ill, is now out of danger, though very weak.

div.head: CHRONIQUE JUDICAIRE
div.p: TRIBUNAL SOMMAIRE MIXTE D'ALEXANDRIE LES AGIBSBMENTS D'UN BOAB Plerre Gilly contre Hag Mohamed Hassan Pierre Gilly avait pris en locstion pour un terme d'une annee à partir du ler juin 1904 et au loyer annuel de £ 50 un ap- partement, au rez-de-chaussee de l'im- meuble appartenant a Hag-Mobamed Has- Ban, et sis N° 8 rue d'Allemagne. Il avait paye par anticipation le 1er semestre. Deax mois apres, Gilly demandait la résiliation du contrat et 30 E de dommagea interets a cause de l'attitude vexatoire et des agissements malséants du boab de l'im- meuble, l'introdnetion de vive force de ca dernier dans l'appartement et le refus du proprietaire de renvoyer un boab aussi insolent. Outre la restitution du loyer à courir et les 80 livres d'indemnite pour travaux d'amenagement, M. Gilly recia- mait 6 livres qu'il dissit avoir verse par errear en plus du paiement du ler se- mestre. Le proprietaire conteste énergiquement la véracité de tous ces faits et demande en outre à faire ls preuve que 1° vers la fin du moin de juillet, à 3 heures et demie, le cawas du consulat de France, Aly Moussa, et celui du consulat d'Italie, Mohamed Aly, vinrent socompagnes d'une dame et en- leverent de force au demandeur une jeune fille qu'il detenait dans son appartement, causant ainsi du scandale. 2° Qa'à la suite de ce fait le Sr Mekonian Artaki quitta. l'appartement par lui occupé. 8° Qae vers le milieu du mois d'Aout apres minuit, le demandeur accompagne d'une dame fit son entree dans l'immeuble en faisant du tapage et reveillant les locataires. Selon M. Gilly, la verite serait qu'une tentative de chantage, tramée contre lui, se serait denouée sur la simple interven- tion du consulat d'Italie sans bruit ni tapage, sans l'appareil exterieur qu'a bien voula pour les besoins de sa défense ima- giner Hag Mohamed Hassan. Locataire et propriétajre ont éte admis a faire la preuve de leurs assertions.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: La Banque Nationale accentue anjour- d'hui son mouvement ascensionnel. De 21 18/16, coues de samedi, elle monte à 22 7/16. Il y a tres peu de flottant et c'est a quoi il faut sans doute attribuer la hausse continue de ces jours derniers et particulierement de ce matin. On a fait cirouler plusieurs rameurs, entre autres la vante d'une bonne partie des actions de l'Agricole detenues par la Banque. Cette vente lui rapporterait un profit de 150,000 livres. Rien cependant n'est encore venue confirmer cette nouvelle. Qaoiqu'il en soit, le ton est excessive- ment ferme et la tendance de la valeur à la bausse. Ls Daïra hausse également de 21 9/16 à 21 11/16, la Crown Brewery de 207 à 208, les Cotton Mills de 6/9 à 7 et la Ramleh Railway de 8 1/4 à 8 5/16 acheteurs. Le marche en general est anime, avec ten dance,marquee a la hausse.

div.head: AVIS
div.p: Le Conreil d'Administration |a l'honnenr de porter and la connsissance du poblie qu'il recevra jusqu'sa mercredi 80 novembre 1904 des offrer pour Is fournitare de wagons, suivant le Cahier dea Charges et la liste, dont on peut obtenir copie a l'Administration Centrale (Burean des Aohats) an Caire, au Buresn Central. des Magarins à Boulao (Caire) et auz Magasins de Gabbary a Alexsndrie contre paiement de 100 m,m. Une série complete d'échantillons eat 6gale- ment à la disposition des interesses au prix de L.E. 0.800 m/m. Les offees devront eire 'socompagnees d'ane feuille de papier timbre de 30 Milliemes .- Elles seront adressees par la poste sous pli rocom- mandé à : Monsiear le President Chemins de for de l'Etat Caire, et sous double enveloppe, l'interieure por- tant la susoription suivante :- "Offre pour la Fourniturs de Wagons." L. Conseil ne s'engage pas and nocepter l'offre la plas bssse, ni A donner suile aux soumissions prosentoee, et il se roserve le droit de diviser la commande. Le Caire, le 19 Ootobre 1904. 24,798-1

div.p: Remarques sur le marché du disponible et Contrats.
Samedi, le 22 octobre 1904.

Coton: Disponible. La demande pour le disponible a été assez régulière, sans cependant avoir beaucoup d'importance dans l'ensemble. Elle a continué aussi à porter sur les qualités Mit-Afifi qui, grâce au développement des arrivages, offrent maintenant plus de choix aux acheteurs. A noter toutefois, que ce n'est que le marchandise entre 15 et 15 1/2 qui est recherchée.

Les provenances Haute-Egypte sont toujours négligées. Quant aux prix, ils restent relativement soutenus et cela à cause des contrats. "Franco-gare": On ne signale aucune affaire. Contrats.-Récolte actuelle. Après une baisse marquée et rapide, la fermeté a prévalu sur notre marché et, graduellement, les cours ont regagné une grande partie du recul. Comme nous l'avons déjà dit, c'est ls spéculation senle qui domine le marché en négligeant les nouvelles de l'Etranger, la réserve de la filature, l'abstention du commerce et la modé. ration des expéditions, et en ne se basant que sur les E avis plus ou moins véridiques att sujet de notre récolte. Bref, la tendance est pour la hausse pour Nouvelle récolte. Ona inauguré mardi dernier les affaires sur la prochaine récolte. Le prix de debut a ete t.1. 18 8/4 pour le novembre, mais les affaires restent insignifiantes, mslgre les dispositions des vendeure and scoorder des concessions. Dana la matinee; Priz plns baut pour nov., tolaria 14 5/8 à -/ - : plus bas pour nov. 14 7/16-/ -. Comme prix la semsino finit à P.T. 58 10,40. LA demande ponr le dehors est tonjoar. petite. Franoo-gare" : Il ne se fait presque rien, l'exportation n'ayant pss d'engsgemenis sur l'avenir pour se presser A s'assurer la marchandise. Contrats. - Rocolte actaelle. Les affaires n'y sont pas regalieres, ni importantes ; tontefois, les conrs sont fermes, les vandeurs serienz ne ceisant, d'antre part, de foire defaut. Dane ls matinde, p-ir pius bant pour nov .- do .- jån. div.head: EGYPTIAN MINING ACTIVITY.
div.p: In view of the existing activity in Egyptian Mining, the Directors of the London and Paris Exchange have retained the services of a competent Mining Engineer, whose reports on the present position of the various properties is of the utmost importance. This Information is at the disposal of Clients. Correspondents contemplating Investment in Egyptian Mining Enterprises would be well advised in communicating with the Exchange before doing so, and thus avoid the loss of capital incurred by the purchase of worthless securities.
The London and Paris Exchange undertake the purchase or sale of all classes of Mining Securities on the London Stock Exchange and Continental Sources.

div.head: The Garstin Report
div.p: By Sir Hanbury Brown, K.C.M.G., late In- speetor-General of Irrigation in Lower Egypt, and formerly in Upper Egypt (Coutinued.)

Sir W. Willeocks' basis of caleulstion of the supply required is that a stored quantity of one millised of cuble metres of water is suffi- clent fur the conversion of 300,000 acres to pereanial irrigation; and also that, after tak ing into account the milliard already provided by the Assonsn Reserroir, there still remain 1j million aetes to be converted. Three mil liand eubie metres more are, therefore, according bo has figures, required. One milliard is to be poovided by mising the Assouan Dam 6 m pooposal already diseuseed as the first item of Sir W. Gantin's programime. The remaining two milliards Sir W. Willeocks proposes to roovide by storage in the Wadi Rayan, deprression in the Libyan Desert to the south of the Fayoum, from which it is separated by a lmestone ridge. The depression has, at a leve of about 29 m. abore the ses, a surfsce of 700 equare kilometres, about a quarter of the size of the ancient Lako Moeris. The lowent point of the Wadi is 81 m. below sea-level. 1f Siled with water from the Nile to make i serve as, a reservoir, it will be the top layer only of a few metres' depth that will be utilised to supplement the summer Nile. The proposal t make the Wadi Rayan a reservoir waa Mr. Cop W hitehogse's original conoeptiom;but, originally conceived as an isolated project, ita weak point was that by itself it wonld give a plentiful dis chatge in Apeil and May, less in June, and very little in July, whereas what is wanted i the roverse. Sir W. Willeoeks has now pointed ous that "whem the Asequan Reservoir i capable.of supplying two milliands of eubie metres of frater it will be possible to utilise the Moeris Lake to its atmost capacity. The As souan Reservoir, being high above the level o the Nile, can give its stipply at the beginning or end of the summer: it can give it slowly, or with a rueh, while the projeeted Lak Moeris, being directly in communiention with the Nile, and only slightly above low Nile level, its discharge would depend entirely on th ditferenee of level between it and the Nile, and coseyuently as the entier advanced it would gridually fall, and would not be able to giv at the end of the suminer a quarter of the di charge it could give at the beginning. But us imagine that the reservoir and the lake are both completed, and full of water, and that it is the first of April. Lake Moeris - ie, th Rayan Beservoir-will be opened into the Nile and give all the water peeded in that month while the Assouan Reeervoir will be maintaine at its full level. In May, Lake Moeris will gi yearly the whole sapply and the roservoir wil give a little. In June the lake will giye littl and the reservoir much; while im July the lake will givo practically nothing and the reservoir the whole supply. Working together in thi hanonious manher, the reservoir and the lake which are the true complements of each othe will easily provide the whole of the wate heeded for Egypt." Sir W. Garstin concodes that the schem thus presented is a most attrnetive one. T foejeet of reviving the ancient Lake Moeris i a neighhouring depressioa to that which onc hell the clawical lake has fascinated many tnongst others Sir W. Willoocks ; hence th neressity for withholding judgment on th houject antil its weak poiuts have been examin ed lest its outside personal attractions shoul cbtain for it the approvnl that it mny n doerve. The depression would be flled by einnl connecting it with the Nile acroes 2 kikms. of the ealtivated land of the Ben Snef Province and 16 kiloma, of deser an it weuld take three and a-b o seven yoars to fill, according to differe e-timates, before it began its funetions a reservoir to supplement the low Nile. div.p: A. 8. C. 8KYE MEETING.

Saturday's race meeting was dull and uninteresting, the only notable feature of the afternoon being the entirely unexpected win of Valentino in the race for the San Stefano Plate, when he brought off a 45 to 1 chance. In this race, the riding of Michaelides Jun. was considered unsatisfactory, and he was therefore suspended by the stewards until the end of the year. There was a good deal of betting and the odds in most cases were sufficiently attractive. P.T. 1,300 for a dollar, which was netted by each of the four backers of Valentino, is probably a record for the A.S.C. course. The ground, owing to the rain, was not conducive to fast riding, as the horses skidded a great deal. Owing to the uncertainty which prevailed as regards the elements, a large number of race-goers absented themselves from the meeting, with the consequence that the attendance was exceedingly poor, which added to the dulness of the after- noon, relieved only by the excellent playing of the Royal Berkshire Band under the leader- ship of Bandmaster Dore. The following were the resulta of the various races :-- MAIDEN HURDLE RACE of P.T. 1,250 of which P.T. 250 to go to 2nd horse. For Maiden Arabs. Weight for age, ponies allowed 7 lbs. Distance round the course over 7 flights. Moh. Pasha Chehim's g.a.h. Mizzaud 10.4 Hassan. Mr. Bustros' ch.a.h. Malgre Tout, 10.7 Fen- wick. Ibrahim Bey Cherif'sg.a.h. Mouchir, 10.7 Elias.0 Ibrahim Bey Cherif and Elie Bey Sursock's g.a.h. Arabi, 10.7 Bonser. Malgre Tout came over the last hurdle first, slightly ahead of Mizzaud, who, however, caught him up and won by about t a length, 2 lengths dividing 2nd and 3rd.Betting .- Totalizator paid P.T. 39 on winner and P.T. 41 and 32 respectively for places. PONY PLATE of P.T. 2,500 of which P.T, 500 to go to 2nd horse. For Maiden Arab ponies. Weight for age and inches. Previous winners of any race of advertised value of P.T. 5,000 or more to carry 7lbs. for one win, 10lbs. for two, 14lbs for 3 or more wins, Distance 5 furlongs. Khalil Pasha Khayat's g.a.p. Loulou, 10.1. Jenkins. Mr. A. J. Sursock's g.a.p. Ruy Blas, 10.7. Hassan. Ibrahim Bey Cherif's g.a.p. Sattam, 10.1. Eliseo. Ishak Bey Hussein's ch.a.p. Abou Senoun, 10.8. Aly Farag. Elie Bey Sursock's g.a.p. Nimr, 10.3. Tannous. 0 Mr. M.Tueni's b.a.p. Viking, 10.10. Matthews. 0 Mohar. Pasha Chehim's ch.a.p. Vali, 9.13. Mr: A. J. Michaelides. Ishak Bey Hussein, and Hassan Bey Kheir-el- Din's b.a.p. Faik, 10.7. Stillwell. Mr. A. J. Sursock's g.a.p. Ilaros, 9.11. Vassili. 0 Mr. Jaoques Chalom's g.a.p. Fahr, 10.8. Fenwick. Ibrahim Bey Cherif's c.a.p. Jean, 10.7. Mi- chaelides Jun. Viking and Faik jumped off from a badstart and made the running until they came out of the cutting, followed by Ruy Blas, when Loulou came to the front and won a good race from the latter by a neck. This was a very fast race considering the condition of the ground. Time-1.10. Betting .- Totalizator paid P.T. 102 on wintier, and P.T. 58, 150, and 150 respectively for places. GALLOWAY STAKES of P.T. 2,500 of which P.T. 500 to go to 2nd horse. For Maiden Arab galloways. Weight for age and inches. Distance one mile. Ibrahim Bey Cherif's b.a.p. St .- Frusquin, 9.13. Michaelides Jun. Mr. A. J. Sursock's b.a.p. Sans Pareil, 10.1. Hassan. Baron J. E. de Menasce's ch.a.h. Radium. 10.3. Matthews. Mr. N. Soussa's g.a.p. Habashi, 10.11. Kamel Effendi. Prince Omar Pasha Toussoun's g.a.h. Kohailan, 9.13. Moh. Bastawissi. Mr. A. J. Sursock's g.a.p. Royal Oak, 9.6. Vassili. Habashi declared 3 lb. overweight and Sans Pareil 1 lb. Sans Pareil and St. Frusquin were the first to emerge from the cutting, the others being in a bunch behind. The two mounte maintained their position in the straight and the latter won by about a head, after a close struggle be- tween the pair. Radium was a bad third.

div.head: WHY KIDNEY DISEASE IS SO SERIOUS
div.p: Kidney disease is serious, because it comes on so quietly. It has many syinptoms, but often they are mistaken for other diseases. Headaches, rheumatism, a nervous, irritable condition, weak heart, dropsy, sleeplessness, an always tired feeling, yellow complexion, unnatural urine, too much or'too little urine -these are just as much symptoms of kidney disease as backache, gravel, bladder troubles, etc. Kidney disease may have been working in the' . system for years before the patient suspected the cause of his trouble. That's the danger. Treat the kidneys at the first sign of any ailment. That is the only safe way .. Keep them well, and they will keep you well. Doan's backache kidney pills help the kidneys to filter the blood, and remove from it all disease-breeding impurities. That explains their success. Doan's backache kidney pills are for sale.by all chemists and druggista for P.T. 13 per box, or P.T. 71 for 6 boxes ; or they may be had by post from the general agent for Egypt, Mr. Max Fisher, Hotel du Nil St., Mousky St.,

div.head: A "CAPTAIN COURAGEOUS"
div.p: CAPTAIN ATHERTON, well known on the Merrey, has i three lives to his credit. On a bitter December night, . | hejumped into Garsion Dock, and resoued a mau. He saved a boy in like cirenmetanoes in the Birkenhend Float, and again rioked bia life for a man in the Queen's Dock. Oaptain Atherion speaks lightly of these deeds of heroism. A repre. sentative who called st his house, 270 Price. street, states tbat the gallant oaptain has fell the effeots of a hard life. "Some time ago," mid ho, "my bealth failed. I felt my baok getting weak, and when I stooped it was agony to straighten myeelfagain. I lost appetite, and conld only sleep off and on. I had . bad cough, low spirite and could not touch my brenk fest. I saw Dr. Williams' pink pills mentioned in the paper, and as several friends had been gured by them I bonght boz, and afier taking the pills felt much better. Ikept on with them three or four weeks, and was eured. The weskness in my back disappeared, and I could bend up and down wishout pain. My congh censed and my appetite reitirned." Captin Atherton added shat since his illness he had found the pills a splendid tonio. Captain Atherton's breakdown was serious. The, lumbago and stiffness probably indicated kidney disease, and his lost appetite showed that hia digestion had failed. Dr. Williams' pink pills oured him beosuse they gave him new blood. div.head: 15th ROYAL HUNGARIAN MONEY LOTTERY.
div.p: Under Control of the Hungarian Government.
BY ORDER
of the Royal Hungarian Ministry of Finances the DRAWING 1st CLASS will take place on
24th and 25th November, 1904.
In view of the great demand, those desiring to participate are requested to send in their order immediately to
BANK CHARLES KISS & Co.,
General Agents to the Royal Hungarian Lottery, 92, Andrassy Street, BUDAPEST (Hungary).

table.head: Propsectus of the 15th Royal Hungarian Lottery.

cell.p: The highest prize will, in the luckiest event, amount to CROWNS 1,000,000 (One Million)
The last of these 500 drawn prizes will win the premium.

div.p: GENERAL INSTRUCTIONS.

Oranisation of the lottery. The Royal Hungarian Lottery consists of 110,000 Tickets of which 55,000 will be drawn with prizes and 1 premium. The tickets bear the Royal Hungarian Arma and an English translation.
Drawings. The drawings will take place publicly under the auspices of the Royal Hungarian Government, and in the presence of a State Notary.
Drawing Lists. After the drawings the participants will receive an official list of drawn numbers with prizes.
Correspondence in English, French, Italian, and all principal languages.
The official prospectus will be added to each order and will be sent beforehand on application.

Payment of prizes. All prizes are payable after the drawing in each, on returning the drawn ticket. To our foreign correspondents we transmit small prizes by mail, larger amounts will be paid out in cheques by the medium of banking houses in all large towns of the world.

N.B. To prevent any misapprehension, arising but too frequently in the public mind, we beg to point out that a winning ticket in the Royal Hungarian Lottery, lawfully acquired and paid for, affords its owner the same guarantee for payment as a banknote issued by the Bank of England.
Participation in all Six Drawings.

The majority of clients prefer to secure at once the right to paricipate in all of the six drawings, which is judicious considering the appreciation in value from drawing to drawing, and the great advantage offered, especially by the 6th drawing, when the largest prizes and the premium of 600,000 crowns are drawn, amounting together to more than ten millions of crowns.

In order to enable the purchaser to secure the full advantage thereof, we are prepared to guarantee such participation in all the six drawings against two equal payments: one payment on application, viz:–
Crowns 80 84 fr. 3 6/8 for one Whole Ticket.
And the other before the 5th drawing, but naturally the latter only to be made in case the number of the tivket should not have already won a prize at a previous drawing.

Every order must be accompained by its value by money order, which please fill out in Crowns, on receipt of which the desired tickets will be sent by return of mail. If you prefer remitting bank notes, cheques, coupons, etc., you are requested to have your letter registered.
All orders should be addressed to
CHARLES KISS & Co.
GENERAL AGENTS TO THE ROYAL HUNGARIAN LOTTERY.
92, Andrassy Street, BUDAPEST, (Hungary.)
Drawing 1st class 24th & 25th November, 1904.
Please cut off here
